data.stimulus:
Secondary Research & Discussion

Below is an extract from a report on improving international student flow to Australia.

 

This extract has TWO sections:

► A paragraph from the secondary research

► A paragraph from the discussion

 

1. Read the extracts and choose the correct missing word from the drop-down
data.template:
Secondary Research: Key Drivers

Educational Drivers

Figure 1 shows the educational driver results of the Australia Student Experience Survey (QILT, 2021). In 2020, all three reasons were equally important to international students. However, in 2010 the results varied dramatically. Only around {{response}} of {{response}} {{response}} ‘Institution offered the course I wanted to study’ as a reason for studying in Australia. This number increased each year and reached a peak (96%) in 2020. In addition, results show that ‘quality of teaching’ has become a much bigger priority since 2014 when only {{response}} of {{response}} {{response}} it as important (compared to 96% in 2010 and 92% in 2020). Finally, the importance of the qualification’s reputation has remained steady since 2010 and a large majority (96%) of respondents stated it was important in 2020.

Discussion

Educational Issues

There are two key generalisations to be drawn from the research findings. Firstly, the university should provide a wide range of courses which suit the needs of international students which {{response}} by the fact that the 'Institution offered the course I wanted to study' has become more important for students in recent years. This {{response}} that the university should have a good understanding of the needs of international students in order to provide courses that will be appealing to them. Secondly, teaching quality was highly important which {{response}} that the university should focus on providing the most modern teaching possible. This {{response}} that investing in teaching technology and training could help the university be more competitive in the market.

stems: Uses both past simple and present simple
data.stimulus:
Difference between Secondary Research and Discussion

 

2. Using the example above, decide whether these are features of your secondary research or discussion

Case study: Findings

To help understand the relationship between your secondary research and findings, we will analyse a case study.

 

 

 

► The graph below shows the results of a survey conducted by a property developer who is building a new student accommodation complex.

► They conducted the survey of the target market to find out what facilities they would like.
 

1. Complete the findings below using the data from the bar chart
data.template:
1. The  {{response}} of those questioned wanted a swimming pool built.
  2. A very small {{response}} of the people surveyed were interested in having an arts and crafts centre.
  3. Around  {{response}} of those who responded wanted a library.
  4. Twelve  {{response}} of the people who responded to the survey wished to have a gym included.
  5. Nearly  {{response}} of those questioned wanted a bowling green installed.

Potential residents like outdoor activities and socialising
Reading is quite popular with the respondents
Only a minority enjoy creative activities

data.stimulus:
Generalisations

Earlier, we found out that you should identify the implications (generalisations) of your findings (facts) in your discussion. What are the implications of these findings?

 

2. Read the findings and match them to the implications from the drop-down menu
data.template:
FACT GENERALISATION

1. 40% want a swimming pool and 12% want a gym and aerobics studio.

 {{response}}

2. Around a quarter want a bowling green.

 {{response}}
3. Around 20% want a library. {{response}}
4. Five per cent want an arts and craft centre. {{response}}

value: The target market prefers relaxing acquatic activities to intense exercise.
Potential residents like outdoor activities and socialising
Reading is quite popular with the respondents
Only a minority enjoy creative activities

data.stimulus:
Discussion

► After making generalisations, you then need to write complete sentences and organise your paragraphs. You should combine your facts and generalisations to make a 'generalisation statement'.

 

There are two ways we can do this. We can use the active or the passive:


►Example:

 

REMEMBER: If the generalisation is first, you should use a passive verb. If the fact is first, you should use an active verb.

 

3. Read the discussion of of this case study and choose the correct form of the verb
data.template:
Discussion

There a four significant discussion points based on the research findings. {{response}}, in general the target market prefer relaxing acquatic activities to strenuous exercise which {{response}} by the fact that 40% want a swimming pool but only 12% want a gym. {{response}}, around a quarter want a bowling green which {{response}} that prospective customers like outdoor activities and socialising. {{response}}, reading is quite popular with the respondents which {{response}} by the fact that around 20% of those asked want a library in the building. {{response}}, five per cent of those surveyed want an arts and craft centre which {{response}} that only a minority enjoys creative activities.

value: is suggested by the fact that
is illustrated by the fact that

data.stimulus:
Practice

► Generalisation statements can be written using the active or passive. It's important to use both to make your work more cohesive and also to help your report's language score.

 

4. Connect the two statements below to create a discussion statement. If the generalisation is first ► use a passive verb + 'by the fact that'; if the fact is first ► use an active verb. There is one example done for you.
data.template:
EXAMPLE: 40% of respondents want a swimming pool and 12% want a gym which implies that (imply) the target market prefer relaxing acquatic activities to strenuous exercise.

1. Prospective residents like outdoor activities and socialising which {{response}} (suggest) around a quarter want a bowling green.

2. Around 20% of those asked want a library in the building which {{response}} (indicate) reading is a quite popular with the respondents.

3. Only a minority enjoys creative activities which {{response}} (illustrate) five per cent of those surveyed want an arts and craft centre.

value: is suggested by the fact that
is illustrated by the fact that

stems: Uses both past and present simple verbs
data.stimulus:
Review: The discussion

Based on what we have covered in this lesson, review the statements below to check your understanding of the discussion section of your report.
 

1. Read the statements and decide if they are important for the discussion section by choosing 'yes' or 'no'.

value: Students are motivated by external opportunities

possible_responses: Students are motivated by external opportunities
data.stimulus:
Discussion: Students in Australia

In our previous online lesson we looked at some data from the Australian Student Experience Survey Report (QILT, 2021). Below are the top six reasons for studying in Australia selected by students.

 

 

 

1. Match the facts (on the left) to the generalisations (on the right)
stimulus_list: More than 90% of those surveyed prioritised the reputation of their course, Australia’s education system and of the university
Personal safety and security is important
Ninety-four per cent of those surveyed selected post-course employment opportunities

value: Students are motivated by external opportunities

data.stimulus:
Generalisation statements

As we have covered, we must combine facts and generalisations to create a 'generalisation statement".

The discussion section will contain a number of these statements which demonstrate your understanding of the findings and of the topic in general.

 

► IMPORTANT: A good discussion will show the audience that you have a critical understanding of the research.

 

3. Review the generalisation statements below (in blue) and complete the text by choosing the correct missing word.
data.template: a) Most students {{response}} that prestige is essential {{response}} by the fact that more than 90% of those surveyed prioritised the reputation of their course, Australia’s education system and of the university. {{response}} that having a strong reputation is vital in recruiting the best students and staff (Times Higher Education, 2021) but also in making partnerships with other organisations.

b) {{response}} that personal safety and security is important which {{response}} {{response}} that those studying in Australia wish to have a low-stress environment in order to focus on their studies more effectively. {{response}} 90% of students feel safe off campus and 97% feel safe on campus (see Table 5), it is clear that students are able to work without feeling unsafe.

value: is indicated by the fact that

possible_responses: is indicated by the fact that
data.template: c) Students are also motivated by external opportunities which {{response}} that ninety-four per cent of {{response}} selected post-course employment opportunities as a reason to study in Australia. {{response}} that the University should provide clear routes to employment after graduation to attract more students.

value: is indicated by the fact that
